summary_snippets: Cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin act by cross-linking DNA. Their adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, and ototoxicity. Ototoxicity can manifest as ringing in the ears (tinnitus) and sensorineural hearing loss.

The initial screening test for an HIV infection is the HIV-1 and HIV-2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay. If this test is positive, follow-up testing should use the HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific type of HIV infection.

Patients with a mutation of the merlin gene on chromosome 22 are at risk of developing multiple schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas. The presence of bilateral vestibular schwannomas is a hallmark of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).

Meningiomas frequently have acquired genetic defects, particularly truncating mutations in the neurofibromatosis 2 gene (merlin) on chromosome 22q. These mutations are present in the majority of certain meningiomas, including fibroblastic and transitional types.

The NF2 gene on 22q encodes a cytoskeletal protein, merlin, that functions as a tumor suppressor. NF2 is characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas in over 90% of patients, multiple meningiomas, and spinal ependymomas and astrocytomas.

Segmented genomes confer evolutionary advantages; different strains of a virus with a segmented genome can shuffle and combine genes and produce progeny viruses with unique characteristics. This process is called reassortment. Recombination occurs when viruses infect cells simultaneously and can happen in both RNA and DNA viruses.

Both DNA and RNA viruses can undergo recombination. When two or more viruses of the same type infect a cell, their genomes may recombine to produce recombinant virus progeny. This process is known as multiplicity reactivation and can occur with various pathogenic viruses, including HIV-1, vaccinia virus, and others.

Pitrakinra is an antagonist of the interleukin-4 receptor alpha chain, which is also part of IL-13. It blocks the inflammatory effects of IL-4 and IL-13, interrupting the Th2 lymphocyte immune response.
IL-4 is the positive feedback cytokine for Th2 cells differentiation and stimulates B-cells to produce IgE antibodies, which are involved in allergic reactions.
IL-4 mediates important pro-inflammatory functions in asthma, including induction of isotype rearrangement of IgE, which favors class switching of antibodies.

Pitrakinra shows the ability to inhibit dual actions of IL-4 and IL-13, which can affect the course of the late asthmatic response after allergen challenge. This suggests that targeting IL-4 and IL-13 can reduce the exaggerated response observed during asthmatic attacks.

Alcohol intoxication, also known as alcohol poisoning, can cause symptoms such as slurred speech, poor coordination, and altered mental status. At higher doses, it may lead to respiratory depression, coma, or death. Additionally, physical examination findings may include an alcoholic smell and diminished deep tendon reflexes, consistent with ethanol intoxication.

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is more aggressive in elderly adults. Symptoms in elderly patients may include B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss), swollen lymph nodes, and extra-nodal tissue involvement. The histologic features of DLBCL may include a centroblastic variant, which is dominated by centroblasts, and an immunoblastic variant with 90% immunoblasts.

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common congenital heart defect, and small defects are usually asymptomatic at birth. The condition allows blood to flow between the ventricles, resulting in a holosystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border. VSD is more common among patients with conditions such as Down syndrome, fetal alcohol syndrome, and other genetic syndromes.

Secondary bacterial pneumonia follows acute influenza and is characterized by reappearance of fever, cough, purulent sputum, and signs of consolidation on physical and x-ray examination. The most common bacterial pathogens are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Haemophilus influenzae. It occurs frequently in high-risk individuals, including the elderly, and patients often respond to antibiotic therapy when instituted promptly.

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is characterized by poor oxygen-dependent killing due to an NADPH oxidase defect, leading to recurrent infections and granuloma formation with catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas cepacia, and Aspergillus. The nitroblue tetrazolium test is used to screen for CGD, where leukocytes turn blue if NADPH oxidase can convert oxygen, and remain colorless if NADPH oxidase is defective. MPO deficiency results in an increased risk for Candida infections but most patients are asymptomatic, and in this case, NBT is normal while the respiratory burst is intact.

Mitral regurgitation occurs when the mitral valve fails to close completely, causing blood to flow back into the left atrium during ventricular systole. This backflow implies no true phase of isovolumic contraction, and since the afterload on the ventricle is reduced, end-systolic volume can be smaller than normal.

LEMS is often associated with lung cancer (50–70%), specifically small-cell carcinoma, making LEMS a paraneoplastic syndrome. LEMS may be the first symptom of lung cancer and in most cases is otherwise asymptomatic.

In some conditions, such as myasthenia gravis, muscle strength is normal when resting, but true weakness occurs after the muscle has been subjected to exercise. This is also true for some cases of chronic fatigue syndrome, where objective post-exertion muscle weakness with delayed recovery time has been measured.

HAIR-AN syndrome is characterized by hyperandrogenism leading to oily skin, acne, hirsutism, and menstrual irregularities. Symptoms also include insulin resistance, glucose intolerance, infertility, obesity, and changes in muscle mass. The patient in the scenario exhibits symptoms like acne, unwanted facial hair, irregular menstruation, and elevated plasma glucose levels, which may indicate a connection to HAIR-AN syndrome or related conditions like PCOS.

Signs and symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) include irregular or absent menstrual periods, excess body and facial hair (hirsutism), acne, and potential complications such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, and endometrial cancer. To diagnose PCOS, a woman must have at least two of the following three symptoms: polycystic ovaries, anovulation or oligoovulation, and hyperandrogenism. The patient's history of irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and unwanted facial hair, along with her glucose tolerance test results showing elevated plasma glucose, are consistent with PCOS.

Fomepizole is most effective when given soon after ingestion of ethylene glycol or methanol. Delaying its administration allows for the generation of harmful metabolites. Concurrent use with ethanol is contraindicated because fomepizole prolongs the half-life of ethanol by inhibiting its metabolism. Fomepizole slows the production of acetaldehyde by inhibiting alcohol dehydrogenase.
Ionizing radiation causes breaks in DNA strands.

Radiation causes double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA, which are principal lesions leading to chromosomal abnormalities and gene mutations. DSBs facilitate the production of chromosomal rearrangements and large-scale changes, such as chromosomal deletions.
Direct microscopy of a potassium hydroxide preparation of a skin scraping (known as a KOH test) can confirm the diagnosis of athlete's foot.

KOH test can be used to diagnose fungal infections by examining superficial scrapes of skin under a microscope, allowing for the visibility of fungal elements such as hyphae, septate, or yeast cells. If the KOH test is negative but a fungus is still suspected, the scrapings can be sent for culture.

Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, which can include grimacing, tongue movements, lip smacking, lip puckering, pursing of the lips, excessive eye blinking, and rapid, involuntary movements of the limbs, torso, and fingers. Symptoms may become more pronounced over time and typically do not bother the patient.

Tardive dyskinesia (TD) is a disorder characterized by involuntary, repetitive body movements, including grimacing, tongue protrusion, or lip smacking, along with rapid jerking or slow writhing movements. It occurs as a result of long-term use of dopamine-receptor-blocking medications, such as antipsychotics. The condition typically develops after months to years of use, with about 20% of individuals experiencing interference with daily functioning. The diagnosis is based on symptoms and ruling out other potential causes.

Prolonged spasms of facial muscles, such as lip smacking and excessive blinking, can follow the administration of neuroleptic drugs like haloperidol, resulting in tardive dyskinesia. Tardive orofacial dyskinesia can include symptoms such as choreoathetotic chewing and lip smacking.

The patient exhibits symptoms of tardive dyskinesia, which can include unusual lip smacking, mouth pursing, and excessive blinking. These symptoms often develop slowly and may not cause distress to the patient. Tardive dyskinesia is associated with the use of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol.

Tardive dyskinesia includes involuntary and repetitive facial movements. Symptoms can start slowly and persist even after the dose of the antipsychotic is decreased. Chronic blockade of the D2 receptor is hypothesized to contribute to these effects.
Risperidone has an improved adverse-effect profile compared to haloperidol, but it can increase the risk of gynecomastia.

Risperidone is a potent serotonin and dopamine receptor antagonist. It may cause leukopenia and agranulocytosis in rare instances. The incidence of extrapyramidal side effects is low if the dosage is kept below 6 mg daily.
Risperidone therapy can cause weight gain and gynecomastia as adverse effects.

The muromonab's mechanism of action involves binding to the TCR/CD3 receptor complex, leading to T-cell activation and subsequent lowering of the number of available T-cells by blocking TCR-antigen binding and causing conformational changes or removal of the TCR/CD3 complex. This affects the T-cell response and can lead to anergy or apoptosis without additional signals from co-stimulatory molecules.

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is characterized by a diagnostic triad: microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. Clinical features include pallor, irritability, and symptoms of acute renal failure, such as oliguria and elevated creatinine levels. A blood smear in HUS shows fragmented red blood cells (schizocytes), and laboratory findings may reveal anemia (hemoglobin level typically <80 g/L), low platelet count (often <60,000 platelets/μL), and elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is characterized by thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA), the formation of blood clots in small blood vessels leading to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. Neurological symptoms (confusion, seizures), kidney impairment (elevated creatinine, decreased eGFR), and gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain) may be present. TTP is caused by an acquired defect in the ADAMTS13 protein, and a lab test showing ≤5% of normal ADAMTS13 levels is indicative of TTP.

Clostridium perfringens forms spores that can withstand cooking temperatures, leading to germination and development of infective bacterial colonies. Symptoms typically include abdominal cramping, diarrhea, vomiting, and fever. The course of illness usually resolves within 24 hours but can last up to 2 weeks in older or infirm hosts.

Antibiotics such as metronidazole cause a disulfiram-like chemical reaction with alcohol by inhibiting its breakdown by acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, which may result in vomiting, nausea, and other symptoms.

Acetaldehyde accumulates when ethanol is consumed in the presence of disulfiram, causing unpleasant reactions. Several drugs, including metronidazole, inhibit ALDH and can cause a disulfiram-like reaction if combined with ethanol.

Common physical exam findings in blunt cardiac injury (BCI) include tenderness to palpation of the chest wall and bruising. An ECG is recommended for evaluation, and abnormal findings suggest the need for continuous telemetry monitoring. Troponin levels should also be assessed, as negative results do not exclude BCI. Elevated troponin levels are significant, and if both ECG and troponin levels are abnormal, echocardiography is the next step in evaluation.

Pulmonary contusion is the most common injury found in blunt chest trauma, occurring in 25–35% of cases, usually caused by the rapid deceleration of the chest striking a fixed object. About 70% of cases arise from motor vehicle collisions, and pulmonary contusion can occur without damage to the chest wall. It can also result from falls, assaults, sports injuries, and explosions, with severe pulmonary contusion being a primary cause of death among survivors of explosions.

Transposition of the Great Vessels is the most common cyanotic congenital heart lesion in the newborn. In this condition, the aorta is connected to the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery to the left ventricle, creating parallel pulmonary and systemic circulations. Without a septal defect or a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), it is incompatible with life. Critical illness and cyanosis typically occur immediately after birth. Signs include tachypnea, progressive hypoxemia, extreme cyanosis, and a single loud S2 heart sound may be present. There may not be a murmur if no ventricular septal defect (VSD) is present.

Acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) is the most common form of melanoma diagnosed among Asian and sub-Saharan African ethnic groups. The average age at diagnosis for ALM is between sixty and seventy years. Typical signs of ALM include longitudinal tan, black, or brown streaks on a nail, pigmentation of the proximal nail fold, and areas of dark pigmentation on the palms of hands.
Acral lentiginous melanoma is almost always invasive.

High LDL-cholesterol is indicated for treatment, as it is 186 mg/dL, above the optimal level. The American Heart Association states that statins are effective in lowering LDL cholesterol and are widely used for those at high risk of cardiovascular disease.

Medical therapy with anti-thyroid medications is the treatment of choice for hyperthyroidism in pregnancy. Methimazole and propylthiouracil are effective in preventing pregnancy complications caused by hyperthyroidism. If a woman is already receiving carbimazole, a change to propylthiouracil is recommended, but this should be changed back to carbimazole after the first trimester. Radioactive iodine is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy, and surgery is considered for patients who suffer severe adverse reactions to anti-thyroid drugs, best performed in the second trimester of pregnancy.
Humans become infected with Clonorchiasis sinensis by eating infected fish that has been undercooked, smoked, pickled, or salted.

Infection with Schistosoma species occurs when skin comes into contact with contaminated fresh water in which the snails that carry the parasite are living. The disease can cause symptoms such as bladder cancer, renal failure, and periportal fibrosis. The eggs that do not pass out of the body may become lodged in the bladder, causing inflammation or scarring.

Untreated tetralogy of Fallot rapidly results in progressive right ventricular hypertrophy due to increased resistance from narrowing of the pulmonary trunk, leading to heart failure. The mortality rate for untreated TOF is 35% in the first year of life and 50% in the first three years. Patients with untreated TOF rarely progress to adulthood.

Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, representing about 10% of all congenital heart defects. It consists of four structural defects: ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The condition is due to abnormal septation of the truncus arteriosus into the aorta and pulmonary artery that occurs early in gestation (3 to 4 weeks). The VSD is large, and the pulmonary stenosis is most commonly subvalvular or infundibular.

Antigenic variation in Neisseria gonorrhoeae occurs through genetic recombination of its pili and surface proteins that interact with the immune system. This variation helps the bacteria evade the immune response, which can explain the lack of lasting immunity in infected individuals.

Complete immobilization of the head and neck should be done as early as possible and before moving the patient. Immobilization must remain in place until movement of the head and neck is proven safe. In the presence of severe head trauma, cervical fracture must be presumed until ruled out. Immobilization is imperative to minimize or prevent further spinal cord injury. The only exceptions are when there is imminent danger from an external cause, such as becoming trapped in a burning building.

Amantadine was investigated for treating symptoms of Parkinson's disease after a patient with the condition reported improvement while taking it for an influenza infection. In a clinical trial with 163 patients diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, 66% experienced reduction of symptoms with a maximum daily dose of 200 mg.

If available, magnesium sulfate is the preferred treatment for seizures in pregnant women. A risk of stopping breathing can occur with magnesium sulfate use, indicating a dosage that is too high. Calcium gluconate can be used to reverse the effects of magnesium sulfate (1g IV over 10 minutes) if breathing is compromised. It's important to check that the breathing rate is at least 16 breaths per minute and the knee jerk reflex is intact before administering more magnesium sulfate.
Magnesium sulfate can cause magnesium toxicity, which is indicated by loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs). In cases of magnesium toxicity, treatment includes administering IV calcium gluconate.

The physical examination of an individual with aortic regurgitation includes auscultation to listen for an early diastolic and decrescendo murmur, best heard in the third left intercostal space, and may radiate along the left sternal border. An S3 heart sound (S3 gallop) correlates with the development of left ventricular dysfunction.

BPD is itself a Cluster B disorder. Patients with BPD often exhibit impulsivity and emotional instability, and they may engage in manipulative behaviors in relationships. Short-term hospitalization has not been found to be more effective than community care for improving outcomes for those with BPD.

Individuals with borderline personality disorder develop intense emotional expressions due to reinforcement throughout their development. They may escalate emotional expressions if attention is given to extreme emotional behaviors, such as suicide threats. The disorder is associated with impulsivity, turbulent relationships, and volatile emotions, including alternating between sobbing and anger. Venting is a strategy linked to personality disorder symptoms.

Bird fancier's lung (BFL) is triggered by exposure to avian proteins and causes symptoms like dry cough, fever, and fatigue. It is diagnosed based on symptoms worsening with exposure to birds. Treatment includes removal of exposure to avian proteins and may involve steroids like prednisone to reduce inflammation. If pulmonary fibrosis has not occurred, treatments tend to be very effective.

Zika fever is an infectious disease caused by the Zika virus. Most cases are asymptomatic, but symptoms can include fever, headache, joint pain, red eyes, and a maculopapular rash, lasting less than seven days. In pregnant women, Zika infection can lead to microcephaly and other brain malformations in infants. The virus is primarily spread by Aedes mosquitoes and can also be sexually transmitted or spread through blood transfusions.

Zika virus can be transferred from a pregnant woman to her fetus and poses a threat as it can cause birth defects, miscarriages, and stillbirths. Common symptoms of the Zika virus include fever, rash, headache, joint pain, red eyes, and muscle pain, which typically last no more than a week.

Zika virus causes Zika fever, which can result in mild symptoms resembling dengue fever, including fever, red eyes, joint pain, headache, and a maculopapular rash. Infection during pregnancy can lead to microcephaly and other brain malformations in some babies. There have been no reported deaths from Zika virus during the initial infection, and it has been associated with Guillain–Barré syndrome. Diagnosis of Zika virus is performed by testing for the presence of Zika virus RNA in blood, urine, or saliva.

DMD can be detected with about 95% accuracy by genetic studies performed during pregnancy. DNA testing confirms the diagnosis in most cases. The muscle-specific isoform of the dystrophin gene is composed of 79 exons, and DNA testing can usually identify the specific type of mutation of the exon or exons that are affected.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is caused by a mutation in the gene for the protein dystrophin, which is crucial for maintaining the muscle fiber's cell membrane. It primarily affects boys, with muscle weakness typically starting around age four and rapidly progressing, leading to loss of the ability to walk by age 12. The disorder is X-linked recessive, with two thirds of cases inherited from the mother and one third due to new mutations. Affected individuals present with high levels of creatine kinase in their blood.

Diverticulitis typically presents with lower quadrant abdominal pain of sudden onset, and patients often have elevated C-reactive protein and a high white blood cell count. In North America, abdominal pain is usually on the left lower side. Symptoms may also include fever, nausea, diarrhea or constipation, and blood in the stool.

Diverticulitis is characterized by severe left lower quadrant pain, which can occur following a history of symptoms such as bloating, constipation, and diarrhea. Fever, chills, and constipation are typically present, and localized tenderness can be observed in the left lower quadrant upon examination. Common lab findings include leukocytosis and fever. Abdominal examination may reveal a poorly mobile inflammatory mass.

Aortoiliac occlusive disease is characterized by claudication of the buttocks and thighs, erectile dysfunction, and a triad of symptoms known as Leriche syndrome. Symptoms may vary based on distribution and severity, which include muscle atrophy, slow wound healing in the legs, and critical limb ischemia.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common cause of chest pain, especially if it worsens with large meals and spicy foods. The use of calcium carbonate may relieve symptoms associated with GERD.
The current drug of choice to treat infection with Borrelia mayonii in the early stages is doxycycline, an antibiotic, over a 2- to 4-week course.

The major risk factor for urothelial (transitional cell) carcinoma is cigarette smoke. Additional risk factors include exposure to naphthylamine, azo dyes, and long-term use of cyclophosphamide or phenacetin. Urothelial carcinoma typically presents with painless hematuria and is commonly seen in older adults.

Tobacco use is the most frequent risk factor for bladder cancer, followed by occupational exposure to various carcinogenic materials such as industrial solvents (e.g., aromatic amines). Other risk factors include arsenic, radiation, cyclophosphamide, and chronic exposure to foreign bodies (stones and catheters) and specific urinary parasites. The most common bladder cancer histology in the United States is urothelial carcinoma (UC), which accounts for 90% of tumors.

Chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy is caused by disruption in the dynamics of neurotubules by chemotherapy drugs, leading to symptoms such as pain, numbness, tingling, and muscle weakness in limbs. Tubulin inhibitors affect the stability and dynamics of microtubules, which are responsible for chromosome segregation during mitosis, and suppress tumor growth.

Vinca alkaloids, including vincristine, inhibit the assembly of microtubules, disrupting axonal transport in peripheral nerves. This action leads to sensorimotor neuropathy characterized by symptoms such as muscle weakness, initial pain, cramping, and decreased sensation in the hands and feet. The most neurotoxic of the vinca alkaloids is vincristine, which specifically disrupts the microtubular axonal transport system, causing axonal neuropathy, distal numbness, tingling, and pain.

Vincristine commonly complicates treatment with peripheral neuropathy, with paresthesias as the most common early symptom and loss of ankle jerks as an early sign. This neuropathy is strictly dose-related, and reduction in dosage can lead to improvement of symptoms over several months.

Chemotherapy drugs associated with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) include vincristine, and symptoms may include tingling, numbness, pain, and hypersensitivity to cold, primarily affecting sensory nerves but can also impact motor and autonomic nerves.

The first clinical sign of minimal change disease is usually edema, which can present as periorbital edema and swelling in the lower half of the body. In older adults, it may also lead to acute kidney injury and high blood pressure. Pathologically, minimal change disease is characterized by no changes under light microscopy, hence the name, and may show expanded mesangium. There are no immunoglobulins or complement deposits bound to kidney tissue under immunofluorescence.

Theca lutein cyst is a type of bilateral functional ovarian cyst filled with clear, straw-colored fluid. To be classified as a functional cyst, the mass must reach a diameter of at least three centimeters.

Greater than 45 years of age, male, and history of suicide attempt or self-injurious behaviors are factors associated with an increased risk of suicide. Additionally, having psychotic features increases the risk, particularly during a major depressive episode.

Sleep disorders can increase the risk of psychosis and worsen the severity of psychotic episodes. Insomnia is a significant predictor of major depressive disorder and indicates a more than twofold increased risk for major depressive disorder.

The risk factors for suicidal ideation can be divided into psychiatric disorders, life events, and family history. Individuals with borderline personality disorder exhibit a significant risk, with 73% having attempted suicide. A history of previous suicide attempts is a strong predictor of suicidal ideation.

Rubella has symptoms similar to flu, with the primary symptom being the appearance of a facial rash that spreads to the trunk and limbs, usually fading after three days. Other symptoms include low-grade fever, swollen glands (sub-occipital and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy), joint pains, headache, and conjunctivitis.
Mutations in the apolipoprotein C-II gene (APOC2) cause hyperlipoproteinemia type IB, which is characterized by pancreatitis, along with xanthomas and hepatosplenomegaly.

Gitelman syndrome is characterized by hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and low serum levels of potassium, sodium, chloride, and magnesium. There is high or inappropriately normal urinary fractional excretion of potassium in the context of hypokalemia, along with elevated levels of urinary sodium and chloride. Clinical indicators also include elevated serum renin and aldosterone, and the symptoms can range from mild (weakness, cramps) to severe (tetany, paralysis, rhabdomyolysis).

Bartter syndrome consists of low levels of potassium in the blood, alkalosis, normal to low blood pressures, and elevated plasma renin and aldosterone. Diagnostic pointers include high urinary potassium and chloride despite low serum values, increased plasma renin, and hyperplasia of the juxtaglomerular apparatus on kidney biopsy. Excess production of prostaglandins by the kidneys is often found. Magnesium wasting may also occur.
Those affected by Sjögren's syndrome are at an increased risk (15%) of lymphoma.

The anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibodies primarily attack the kidneys and lungs. Common symptoms include coughing up blood, chest pain, cough, shortness of breath, blood in the urine, protein in the urine, unexplained swelling of limbs or face, high amounts of urea in the blood, and high blood pressure. 60 to 80% of those with Goodpasture syndrome experience both lung and kidney involvement.
C: Linear IgG staining on immunofluorescence is indicative of anti-GBM disease.

In Goodpasture syndrome, IgG antibodies directed against the glomerular basement membrane trigger an inflammatory reaction, causing a nephritic syndrome and coughing up of blood. Immunohistochemistry staining of tissue specimens shows linear IgG deposits.

Asbestosis is long-term inflammation and scarring of the lungs due to asbestos fibers. Symptoms may include shortness of breath, cough, wheezing, and chest tightness. Diagnosis is based upon a history of exposure together with medical imaging. Asbestosis is a type of interstitial pulmonary fibrosis.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy usually resolves within a few weeks but can lead to serious complications like congestive heart failure and very low blood pressure. In acute heart failure, ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and beta blockers are mainstays of treatment, although the use of beta blockers specifically for takotsubo cardiomyopathy is controversial.

Length time bias is an overestimation of survival duration due to the relative excess of cases detected that are asymptomatically slowly progressing, while fast progressing cases are detected after giving symptoms. It can lead to the perception that screening leads to better outcomes when in reality it has no effect. Fast-growing tumors generally have a shorter asymptomatic phase than slower-growing tumors.
The lead time itself biases survival statistics: people with disease detected by screening appear to have a longer survival only because screening starts the clock sooner.

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a type of degenerative joint disease resulting from the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone. Common symptoms include joint pain and stiffness that progress slowly over time, typically becoming constant. Symptoms may include joint swelling and decreased range of motion. The most commonly affected joints are those at the ends of the fingers, the base of the thumbs, the knees, hips, neck, and lower back. Joints on one side of the body may be more affected than those on the other. Unlike other types of arthritis, osteoarthritis affects only the joints and not internal organs.

Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by motor paralysis on the same side (ipsilateral) as the spinal cord lesion and deficits in pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side (contralateral). If the lesion occurs above T1, it can also produce ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

Chlamydia is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Symptoms may include burning with urination, and in men, discharge from the penis or pain and swelling of one or both testicles. The infection can lead to complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease in women, potentially resulting in infertility or ectopic pregnancy.

In men, chlamydial infection can lead to symptoms of infectious inflammation of the urethra, including burning sensation when urinating and increased urinary frequency. If untreated, it may spread to the testicles, causing conditions like epididymitis.

BSS (Bernard–Soulier syndrome) presents as a bleeding disorder due to the inability of platelets to bind and aggregate at sites of vascular endothelial injury. BSS platelets do not aggregate to ristocetin, and this defect is not corrected by the addition of normal plasma, distinguishing it from von Willebrand disease. Bleeding events can be controlled by platelet transfusion, and in cases of mucosal bleeding, tranexamic acid can be administered.

Giant platelet disorder, also known as macrothrombocytopenia, features abnormally large platelets, thrombocytopenia, and a tendency to bleeding. Symptoms include nosebleeds, bruising, and gum bleeding, which can present from birth to early childhood. This disorder can lead to abnormal bleeding caused by any factors like surgery, trauma, or menstruation, and is associated with inherited diseases such as Bernard-Soulier syndrome. Symptoms include prolonged bleeding time and too few platelets circulating in the blood.

Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is a rare coagulopathy caused by defective or low levels of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GpIIb/IIIa), leading to impaired fibrinogen bridging of platelets. This results in a significantly prolonged bleeding time. Characteristic signs include mucosal bleeding, easy bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding from the gums, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Platelet numbers and morphology are normal, and platelet aggregation is normal with ristocetin, but impaired with other agonists such as ADP, thrombin, collagen, or epinephrine.

Ketamine is an NMDA-receptor antagonist that has shown promise in preventing or reversing opioid-induced tolerance and can reduce postoperative pain and opioid requirements in opioid-tolerant patients.
Th1 cells secrete IFN-gamma, which stimulates phagosome-lysosome fusion within macrophages and activates them to produce mediators such as nitric oxide (NO) for pathogen destruction.

IFNγ activates macrophages to enhance their ability to kill intracellular organisms, allowing macrophages to overcome the inhibition of phagolysosome maturation caused by mycobacteria. Th1 helper cells secrete IFNγ, which activates macrophages and leads to further killing of intracellular bacteria, as well as the formation of granulomas.
Bromocriptine is used in the treatment of hyperprolactinaemia, which is associated with conditions like amenorrhea and infertility. It is also used to treat Parkinson's disease.

Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) provide numerous noncontraceptive benefits, including decreased acne. They suppress gonadotropin secretion, inhibit ovarian follicle development and ovulation, and produce an atrophic endometrium, making it inhospitable for blastocyst implantation. COCs are also 99% effective if taken regularly.
Normal ascension of the kidneys during embryological development is commonly arrested by the inferior mesenteric artery due to the central fusion of the kidneys.
Horseshoe kidneys get trapped under the inferior mesenteric artery and remain low in the abdomen during fetal development.
Vaccination for S. pneumoniae, H. influenza, and N. meningitidis should be given pre-operatively if possible to minimize the chance of overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI).

For women > 21 years of age with CIN I, the mainstay of treatment is close observation, which includes Pap smear screening at 6 and 12 months and/or HPV DNA testing at 12 months. After two Pap smears or a DNA test, patients can be managed with routine annual follow-up. Persistent CIN I can be treated with ablative (cryotherapy or laser ablation) or excisional therapy (loop electrosurgical excision procedure [LEEP]; laser and cold-knife conization). For women ≤ 21 years of age, HPV testing is not recommended.
The spontaneous regression rate of biopsy-proven CIN 1 is 60% to 85% within a 2-year follow-up. Expectant management is appropriate for some patients with LSIL that persists longer than 2 years.

Acalculous cholecystitis accounts for 5–10% of all cases of cholecystitis and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. It is typically seen in people who are hospitalized and critically ill and can be associated with vasculitis, chemotherapy, major trauma, or burns. The presentation of acalculous cholecystitis is similar to calculous cholecystitis. Ultrasonography often shows an immobile, enlarged gallbladder.

In restrictive lung disease, the FEV1 and FVC are equally reduced due to fibrosis or other lung pathology. The FEV1/FVC ratio should be approximately normal, or even increased, because of the decrease in magnitude of FVC as compared to FEV1.

Newborns exposed to HIV in utero whose mothers were on antiretroviral therapy (ART) and achieved viral suppression by delivery should be administered zidovudine for 4 weeks to prevent HIV transmission following delivery.

All newborns who were exposed to HIV in utero should receive postpartum antiretroviral drugs within 6 hours of delivery, and their dosing should be based on the newborn's gestational age. Premature newborns should only receive zidovudine, lamivudine, and/or nevirapine based on toxicity testing.
Newborns of HIV-infected mothers should be treated with zidovudine for 6 months after birth. Women with <1000 copies of plasma HIV RNA/ml have a transmission risk of approximately 1%.

Glybuzole is a sulfonylurea that lowers blood glucose levels by binding to receptors at β-pancreatic cells. This binding blocks ATP-dependent channels for K+ ions, leading to cell membrane depolarization. Consequently, calcium ions flow into the cell, causing the exocytosis of insulin, which decreases blood glucose levels.

The document describes a condition characterized by the absence of melanocytes, leading to hypopigmented skin. This condition can be chronic and progressive and is diagnosed by the absence of melanocytes in a skin biopsy. It also mentions that conditions to rule out include postinflammatory hypopigmentation and provides context on the autoimmune associations with some patients.

Older children presenting with coarctation of the aorta may be asymptomatic or have symptoms such as leg discomfort with exercise, headache, or epistaxis. Physical examination may reveal decreased or absent lower extremity pulses, hypertension in the upper extremities, and a murmur best heard in the left interscapular area of the back. If significant collaterals have developed, continuous murmurs may be heard throughout the chest.

Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by diminished and delayed femoral pulses, a systolic pressure gradient between the upper and lower limbs, and may present with a blowing systolic murmur in the posterior left interscapular areas. Patients often exhibit hypertension in the upper body compared to the lower body. Physical findings include loud heart sounds (like loud S1 and S2) and potentially an S4. Diagnosis can be confirmed by chest x-ray, which may show notching of the ribs.

Coarctation of the aorta presents with a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, a systolic murmur or radiofemoral delay. Signs include a brachiofemoral delay in the pulse and may show notching of the ribs on chest X-ray.
An upper-to-lower extremity gradient of more than 10 to 20 mm Hg suggests coarctation of the aorta.

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital abnormality characterized by the constriction of the aortic lumen distal to the left subclavian artery, leading to diminished blood supply to the lower limbs and abdomen. Long-standing cases can develop collateral vessels resulting in inferior rib notching, visible on chest radiographs. This condition also increases the workload on the heart, potentially leading to cardiac failure.

PTHrP is related in function to parathyroid hormone and can lead to hypercalcemia when secreted by a tumor, considered a paraneoplastic phenomenon. PTHrP stimulates bone resorption and distal tubular calcium reabsorption, but does not increase intestinal calcium absorption. The patient's elevated serum calcium concentration of 15.1 mg/dL and low PTH concentration of 9 pg/mL suggests hypercalcemia is not due to primary hyperparathyroidism, indicating a possible malignant cause.
Patients suffering from xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) are deficient in XP proteins required for nucleotide excision repair of pyrimidine dimers in ultraviolet radiation–damaged DNA.
Microscopic examination of medullary thyroid cancer will show an amyloid stroma with hyperplasia of parafollicular cells.

Malignant thyroid cancers are most often carcinomas. Cancer can occur in any tissue that the thyroid consists of, including cancer of C-cells. A risk factor for thyroid cancer is radiation of the head and neck. Cancer is more common in women than men, occurring at a rate of about 2:1.

Most malignant thyroid cancers are papillary, followed by follicular, medullary, and thyroid lymphoma. Thyroid cancer typically presents as a painless mass in the neck. A biopsy of medullary thyroid cancer would likely demonstrate stromal amyloid deposition.
Hyaline cartilage matrix is primarily made of type II collagen and chondroitin sulfate.

Finasteride may improve symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) such as difficulty urinating, nocturia, hesitation at the start and end of urination, and decreased urinary flow. It provides less symptomatic relief compared to alpha-1 blockers and has a slower onset of therapeutic results. In long-term studies, finasteride reduces the risk of acute urinary retention and the need for surgery if the drug is continued.

Medical therapy for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) includes α-blockers (e.g., terazosin), which relax smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, and 5α-reductase inhibitors (e.g., finasteride), which inhibit the production of dihydrotestosterone.
Microcytic and hypochromic red blood cells are seen in thalassemia intermedia, which resembles the blood cells of severe iron-deficiency anemia.

Actinic keratosis (AK) is a pre-cancerous area of thick, scaly, or crusty skin induced by ultraviolet (UV) light exposure. It is more common in fair-skinned individuals and those frequently exposed to the sun. If left untreated, actinic keratosis may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, with untreated lesions having up to a 20% risk of progression. Treatment by a dermatologist is recommended.

Seborrheic keratosis is the most common benign skin tumor. Incidence increases with age, and 100% of patients over age 50 have at least one seborrheic keratosis. The onset is usually in middle age, but they can also be found in younger patients.

Seborrheic keratosis tumors (lesions) appear in various colors, from light tan to black, and can be round or oval, flat or slightly elevated, resembling a scab from a healing wound. They are often described as having a "pasted on" appearance and may occur in association with other skin conditions, including basal cell carcinoma. The differentiation in clinical examination includes warts and melanoma.

Supplementation of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) can be used as treatment for a rarer form of hyperphenylalaninemia, which occurs when the PAH enzyme is normal and a defect is found in the biosynthesis or recycling of BH4. This coenzyme is necessary for proper activity of the enzyme PAH.

Tyrosine cannot be synthesized from phenylalanine in patients with phenylketonuria, making tyrosine an essential amino acid that must be supplied in the diet. Dietary treatment must begin during the first 7–10 days of life to prevent intellectual disability, and lifelong restriction of phenylalanine is recommended to prevent cognitive decline.

Positive HFE analysis confirms the clinical diagnosis of haemochromatosis in asymptomatic individuals with increased iron stores. The alleles evaluated by HFE gene analysis are evident in approximately 80% of patients with haemochromatosis. A negative report for HFE gene does not rule out haemochromatosis. First-degree relatives of those with primary haemochromatosis should be screened to determine if they are carriers or could develop the disease.
Hereditary hemochromatosis is most commonly related to the HFE gene. The disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Fasting transferrin saturation values in excess of 45%, and the serum ferritin more than 250 ug/l in males and 200 ug/l in females are recognized as a threshold for further evaluation of haemochromatosis. Transferrin saturation greater than 62% is suggestive of homozygosity for mutations in the HFE gene.

All adult first-degree relatives of patients with hemochromatosis should be tested for the C282Y and H63D mutations. Testing for HFE of the other parent is helpful for children of an identified proband.
The patient has hereditary hemochromatosis, which results from mutations to the HFE gene. Hepcidin, regulated by the HFE gene, is responsible for iron overload in the condition.

Raw meat can carry various pathogens, with some found in beef including Salmonellas, Escherichia coli, Shigella, Staphylococcus aureus, and Listeria monocytogenes. Contaminated poultry often has different varieties of Salmonellas. Symptoms from these infections typically involve intestinal damage, such as those caused by E. coli, which can include bloody diarrhea and severe abdominal pain. Staphylococcus aureus is associated with rapid onset gastrointestinal symptoms, such as abdominal pain and diarrhea, especially when food is left unrefrigerated.

Common symptoms of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning include rapid onset nausea, explosive vomiting for up to 24 hours, abdominal cramps/pain, and diarrhea. Symptoms typically start 1 to 6 hours after eating contaminated food and usually resolve in less than 12 hours.
Cholera is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, which is transmitted via food or water contaminated with fecal matter. Symptoms include watery diarrhea and vomiting that can lead to dehydration.

A male with hemophilia A cannot pass the mutated gene to his sons, only to his daughters. Thus, the daughters can only be carriers if they inherit the mutation from their mother (if she is a carrier). Since the man has three unaffected daughters, it indicates that their mother has not passed on the mutation. Therefore, there is no chance that the daughters will inherit hemophilia from their father, and the probability that the second daughter is a carrier is dependent on the mother's genetic status.

Diagnosis is made by MRI and lumbar puncture, revealing increased lymphocytes, increased immunoglobulins with oligoclonal IgG bands on high resolution electrophoresis, and myelin basic protein in cerebrospinal fluid analysis.

Cerebrospinal fluid testing can provide evidence of chronic inflammation in the central nervous system. The cerebrospinal fluid is tested for oligoclonal bands of IgG on electrophoresis, which are inflammation markers found in 75–85% of people with multiple sclerosis.

Oligoclonal bands (OCBs) are used in the diagnosis of various neurological diseases, especially multiple sclerosis. They can be detected using methods such as protein electrophoresis or isoelectric focusing combined with silver staining, with the latter being more sensitive. In cerebrospinal fluid analysis, it is noted that proteins present in the CSF but not in the serum are considered to be produced intrathecally.
Oligoclonal bands may be detected in CSF but not in serum, suggesting intrathecal antibody production.

Women with gestational diabetes (GDM) may have high glucose levels in their urine (glucosuria), but dipstick testing is known to perform poorly. Increased glomerular filtration rates during pregnancy lead to glucosuria in about 50% of women at some point during their pregnancy. The sensitivity of glucosuria for GDM in the first two trimesters is only around 10%, with a positive predictive value of about 20%.

Humans with mutations in FOXP3 suffer from a severe and rapidly fatal autoimmune disorder known as Immune dysregulation, Polyendocrinopathy, Enteropathy X-linked (IPEX) syndrome, which is indicative of increased risk for autoimmune disorders.

The IPEX syndrome is characterized by overwhelming systemic autoimmunity in infants, which includes a triad of watery diarrhea, eczematous dermatitis, and endocrinopathy, commonly presenting as insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. Individuals with this syndrome also exhibit other autoimmune phenomena, which include autoimmune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune endocrinopathy. The observed defect is associated with a mutation in the FOXP3 gene.

Individuals with IPEX syndrome experience autoimmune diseases, including enteropathy, type I diabetes mellitus, and eczema, due to a mutation in the FOXP3 gene that leads to dysfunctional regulatory T cells. These individuals develop autoimmune diseases at a young age and have higher immune reactivity and susceptibility to infections.

The X-linked recessive autoimmune syndrome IPEX is characterized by severe allergic inflammation, autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, and is typically caused by mutations in the FOXP3 gene, which is crucial for regulatory T cell function. The autoimmune aspect of IPEX includes autoimmune polyendocrinopathy and can lead to early death.

Keratoacanthoma (KA) is a common low-grade skin tumour that is rapidly-growing and believed to originate from the hair follicle. It is dome-shaped, symmetrical, surrounded by inflamed skin, and capped with keratin scales and debris. It grows quickly, reaching large sizes within days or weeks, and if untreated, it will necrose, slough, and heal with scarring. KA is commonly found on sun-exposed skin such as the face, forearms, and hands, and is characterized by an exophytic nodule with central invagination filled with keratin. Minimal keratinocyte atypia is present.

Angina pectoris is caused by transient, reversible myocardial ischemia, leading to the release of adenosine and other molecules that stimulate autonomic nerves. During exertion, substances such as adenosine are released locally to increase coronary blood flow.

Exposure therapy works better when combined with cognitive behavioral therapy for treating fear of flying. Signs of the fear include intense, persistent anxiety when considering or during flying, which leads to avoidance and significant distress affecting daily functioning.

The bullae in bullous pemphigoid are formed by an immune reaction involving IgG autoantibodies targeting dystonin (bullous pemphigoid antigen 1) and/or type XVII collagen (bullous pemphigoid antigen 2), which are components of hemidesmosomes.

When the tumor is located in the left atrium, symptoms may mimic mitral valve disease with dyspnea and pulmonary edema; although more severe presentations with syncopal episodes, hypotension, and sudden cardiac death have been reported from temporary valve orifice occlusion.

Myxomata are the most common primary cardiac tumors in adults, often found in the left atrium. They can lead to symptoms such as dizziness, fainting, palpitations, and potentially sudden death, especially if they embolize. Pedunculated myxomata may cause stasis and have a "wrecking ball effect," which can lead to embolization.

Anaphylactoid reactions can range from urticaria and itching to bronchospasm and facial and laryngeal edema. For severe reactions such as bronchospasm and facial or neck edema, appropriate treatments include albuterol inhaler or subcutaneous or IV epinephrine, along with diphenhydramine. If respiration is compromised, establishing an airway is crucial before medical management.

This disease is associated with conditions such as endometrial cancer. Signs and symptoms of PCOS include irregular menstrual periods, excess body and facial hair, and enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts, which are present in this patient. To have PCOS, a woman must exhibit at least two of three symptoms: polycystic ovaries, anovulation/oligoovulation, and hyperandrogenism.

Rifaximin is effective for treating hepatic encephalopathy, has minimal side effects, prevents recurring encephalopathy, and is associated with high patient satisfaction. It reduces intestinal ammonia-producing bacteria, alleviating symptoms and reducing mortality.
Diverticular disease is more common in collagen disorders such as Ehlers Danlos Syndrome.

Atrial natriuretic peptide decreases sodium reabsorption in the nephron and inhibits renin secretion, which inhibits the production of angiotensin and aldosterone. It also inhibits the renal sympathetic nervous system.

Several criteria have been described to standardize the diagnosis of mixed connective tissue disease (MTD), including the presence of high titres of anti-RNP antibodies, Raynaud's phenomenon or swollen hands/fingers, and clinical manifestations of at least two other connective tissue diseases such as lupus, scleroderma, or polymyositis. Even with low anti-RNP antibody titers, symptoms can still be present, and high titers do not guarantee symptoms.

Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is characterized by elevated blood levels of anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein (RNP) autoantibodies along with symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis.

Diagnosis of mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) is distinguished by a positive, speckled anti-nuclear antibody and an anti-U1-RNP antibody. MCTD is considered a distinct clinical entity by the majority of rheumatologists, although some patients may evolve towards another connective tissue disease. Various clinical manifestations can suggest MCTD over other connective tissue diseases.

The presence of elevated titers of anti-U1 RNP antibody is a good predictor of progressing to mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) and is sine qua non for the diagnosis of MCTD. The typical phenotype of MCTD is correlated with antibodies against protein A’ and 68 kD of the U1 RNP complex.

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the more prevalent subtype of cystic kidney disease, commonly diagnosed in adulthood, and is characterized by enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is due to a single benign tumor known as a parathyroid adenoma in 80% of cases, with the remainder typically being several adenomas. The diagnosis is made by finding elevated calcium and parathyroid hormone (PTH) in the blood. Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs due to vitamin D deficiency, chronic kidney disease, or other causes of low blood calcium.

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative spiral bacterium that colonizes the gastrointestinal system, predominantly the stomach, and triggers a robust immune response leading to moderate to severe inflammation known as gastritis. Signs and symptoms of infection include burning abdominal pain, weight loss, loss of appetite, bloating, burping, nausea, bloody vomit, and black tarry stools. Infection can be detected using a urease breath test.

First trimester HIV testing is recommended for all pregnant women as a part of routine prenatal care to prevent viral transmission to the fetus and protect maternal health. This testing should be conducted early in pregnancy, ideally at the first visit, and is often done alongside other routine lab work.

HIV screening should be performed in all pregnant women, as coinfection with other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is common. Further STI screening should include syphilis, gonococcal, chlamydial, and trichomonal infections.

Women with no prenatal care are considered to be at risk for syphilis, hepatitis B, and HIV, and laboratory screening studies for these are performed. Some states require routine testing for syphilis, hepatitis B, and HIV in all women admitted to labor and delivery units, even if these were done during prenatal care.

Schizotypal personality disorder frequently co-occurs with major depressive disorder, dysthymia, social phobia, obsessive–compulsive disorder, and has high comorbidity with schizoid and paranoid personality disorder. These personality disorders are part of 'Cluster A' conditions.

The hallmark of polymyositis is weakness and/or loss of muscle mass in the proximal musculature, particularly affecting the hip extensors, leading to difficulty in climbing stairs and rising from a seated position. A muscle biopsy may reveal CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration in the endomysium, which is indicative of polymyositis.

The hallmark clinical feature of polymyositis is proximal muscle weakness. Diagnosis includes elevation of creatine kinase, electromyograph (EMG) alteration, and a positive muscle biopsy. Polymyositis tends to respond well to treatment, which is typically corticosteroids.

Polymyositis is characterized by immune-mediated striated muscle inflammation, presenting with symmetric, progressive proximal muscle weakness, pain, and difficulty breathing or swallowing in advanced disease. It most often affects patients aged 50–70 years, with a male-to-female ratio of 1:2.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is usually discovered on routine examination as an asymptomatic thyroid nodule that appears as a neck mass. The mass is normally referred to a fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA) for investigation, which has a very high accuracy. Other investigation methods include ultrasound imaging, which can distinguish solid from cystic lesions and identify calcifications.

Hürthle cell carcinomas tend to occur in older patients, with a median age at diagnosis of approximately 61 years old. They typically present as a painless thyroid mass, and patients with carcinoma usually have larger tumors than those with adenoma. Rarely, Hürthle cell cancer can spread to the lymph nodes, and in some cases, there are distant metastases in the lungs or surrounding bones. It is difficult to differentiate between benign Hürthle cell adenomas and malignant carcinomas based on size and growth pattern.

Most people infected with Trichomonas vaginalis do not have any symptoms. Symptoms experienced include pain, burning or itching in the penis, urethra (urethritis), or vagina (vaginitis). For women, there may also be a yellow-green, itchy, frothy, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Symptoms usually appear within 5 to 28 days of exposure.

P. aeruginosa keratitis can occur due to direct inoculation into the tissue during trauma or surface injury from contact lenses. It is associated with rapid progression, potentially leading to loss of sight, and is considered a medical emergency. Symptoms can include severe pain and visual acuity changes.

Coccidioides immitis can cause a disease called coccidioidomycosis (valley fever). The organism creates a mass that can mimic a lung tumor. Diagnosis may require a tissue sample (biopsy) and confirmation can be done using a Gomori methenamine silver stain to identify characteristic spherules within the tissue.
Exchange transfusion is used in the treatment of sickle-cell disease.

All patients with presumed ITP should be tested for HIV and hepatitis C virus, as platelet counts may be corrected by treating the underlying disease. Secondary causes of ITP should be excluded, which include conditions such as lupus erythematosus and medications.

Common infecting organisms in the context of chronic respiratory infections are Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. Monitoring pulmonary bacterial flora via airway cultures and providing antibiotics based on identified organisms, including aggressive therapy with appropriate antibiotics, is important in controlling chronic infection.

Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa are the three most common organisms causing lung infections in cystic fibrosis patients. Additionally, opportunistic infection due to Burkholderia cepacia complex can occur, especially through transmission from patient to patient.

Brown-Séquard syndrome occurs when the spinal cord is injured more on one side than the other. On the ipsilateral side of the injury, there is a loss of motor function, proprioception, and sensations of vibration and touch. On the contralateral side of the injury, there is a loss of pain and temperature sensations.

Electrical alternans with sinus tachycardia is a highly specific sign for large pericardial effusion, which can be associated with cardiac tamponade. Patients with cardiac tamponade and hemodynamic compromise should have emergency pericardiocentesis.

Struma ovarii is a rare form of monodermal teratoma that contains mostly thyroid tissue, which may cause hyperthyroidism. The vast majority of struma ovarii are benign tumors, but there are malignant cases. Symptoms of hyperthyroidism can include weight loss despite increased appetite, chest palpitations, increased frequency of diarrhea, and heat intolerance.

Pancreas divisum occurs in 6% to 10% of the population but is asymptomatic in over 95% of cases. When symptoms do occur, they are similar to those seen in pancreatitis with typical anatomy, including abdominal pain, typically of sudden onset, located in the left upper quadrant, and often accompanied by nausea and vomiting.

Pancreatic divisum is a congenital anomaly where the pancreatic duct is not formed as a single structure but remains as two distinct dorsal and ventral ducts. Most individuals with pancreas divisum are asymptomatic, but a minority may develop episodes of abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting due to acute or chronic pancreatitis. Diagnosis is typically identified through cross-sectional imaging like MRI or CT. If symptoms or complications arise, treatment may involve a sphincterotomy of the minor papilla.
The most common side effect of niacin is flushing, which is secondary to skin vasodilation. This effect is mediated by prostaglandins and can be decreased by taking concurrent aspirin.
Flushing associated with niacin is mediated by the prostaglandin pathway. Aspirin taken before niacin can prevent flushing by blocking this pathway.
High doses of niacin can cause acute, prostaglandin-mediated flushing. Aspirin can reduce this side effect by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

Most persons experience a harmless cutaneous vasodilation and sensation of warmth after each dose of niacin due to a prostaglandin-mediated effect. Taking aspirin 30 minutes beforehand blunts this effect.
The most frequent side effect of niacin is cutaneous flushing, which is mediated by activating GPR109A in the skin.

Pernicious anemia is caused by a lack of intrinsic factor, which is required to absorb vitamin B12 from food. A lack of intrinsic factor may arise from an autoimmune condition targeting the parietal cells that produce intrinsic factor or against intrinsic factor itself. Atrophic changes of the gastric body and fundus can indicate damage to these parietal cells.
Pernicious anemia involves antibody production against parietal cells, which normally produce gastric acid. Atrophic changes of the gastric body and fundus can occur in this condition.

Celiac disease involves an immune reaction to gluten, specifically a 33–amino acid gliadin peptide. This gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase, allowing interaction with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 on antigen-presenting cells. The subsequent T cell activation leads to tissue damage and mucosal histopathology. Antibodies against tissue transglutaminase and deamidated gliadin are produced, which can be diagnostically useful.

Henoch–Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis caused by deposits of IgA and complement component 3 (C3) in small blood vessels. It usually occurs in small children and may follow an upper respiratory infection. HSP resolves within a couple of weeks as the liver clears out the IgA aggregates.

Common symptoms of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning include rapid onset (1–6 hours after eating), nausea, explosive vomiting for up to 24 hours, abdominal cramps/pain, headache, weakness, diarrhea, and usually a subnormal body temperature. Symptoms typically last less than 12 hours, but some cases may take two or more days to fully resolve.

Travelers' diarrhea (TD) is defined as the passage of unformed stool while traveling and may be accompanied by abdominal cramps, nausea, fever, headache, and bloating. Bacteria cause more than half of cases, with enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) being the most common except in Southeast Asia where Campylobacter is more prominent. The risk of TD is greatest in the first two weeks of travel.

Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) is one of the leading bacterial causes of diarrhea in the developing world and the most common cause of travelers' diarrhea. Infection with ETEC can cause profuse, watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and other symptoms such as nausea, fever, and muscle aches.

C9 polymerizes to form pores in target cell membranes, causing lysis and cell death. It is part of the complement membrane attack complex (MAC), which is important in killing bacterial cells. A deficiency in C9 is associated with infections caused by gram-negative bacteria, specifically Neisseria meningitidis.

Warfarin can lead to a rare but serious complication known as warfarin necrosis, which occurs more frequently shortly after commencing treatment in patients with a deficiency of protein C. This is because warfarin initially decreases protein C levels faster than the coagulation factors, resulting in a paradoxical increase in coagulation tendency, which can cause massive thrombosis and subsequent skin necrosis.

Clinically affected males with Fragile X syndrome typically have a long face with a large mandible, large everted ears, and large testicles (macroorchidism). The syndrome is associated with a mutation in the FMR1 gene and an increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats.

Affected individuals with Fragile X syndrome may show phenotypic abnormalities that become more prominent with age, including a narrow face with large jaw, prominent ears, and macroorchidism in postpubertal males. The disorder is associated with learning disabilities, hyperactivity, and social interaction difficulties.

The first trinucleotide repeat disease identified was fragile X syndrome, characterized by 230 to 4000 CGG repeats in the gene, leading to intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and macroorchidism in males.

Barrett's esophagus is marked by the presence of columnar epithelia in the lower esophagus, replacing the normal squamous cell epithelium—an example of metaplasia. This metaplasia confers an increased risk of adenocarcinoma.

Miglitol is an oral anti-diabetic drug that acts by inhibiting alpha-glucosidase enzymes, preventing the digestion of complex carbohydrates into monosaccharides. This action lowers postprandial hyperglycemia and helps establish greater glycemic control.

α-Glucosidase inhibitors such as miglitol slow the production of glucose from dietary carbohydrates, thereby reducing the postprandial rise in blood glucose in diabetic patients. These drugs have no effect on lactose digestion because lactose contains a β-glycosidic bond, not an α-glycosidic bond.

Sliding hiatal hernias involve the gastroesophageal junction and part of the stomach being displaced above the diaphragm. Patients with sliding hernias may present with GERD symptoms. For paraesophageal hiatal hernias, surgical gastropexy is recommended to prevent gastric volvulus.

Most people infected with Trichomonas vaginalis do not have any symptoms and can be undetected for years. Symptoms experienced include pain, burning or itching in the penis, urethra (urethritis), or vagina (vaginitis). For women, there may also be a yellow-green, itchy, frothy, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Symptoms usually appear within 5 to 28 days of exposure.

Trichomoniasis is caused by the protozoan T. vaginalis. Symptomatic females experience vaginitis with a thin, malodorous, frothy yellow-green discharge, vulvar irritation, and cervical "strawberry hemorrhages." Diagnosis is based on visualization of motile, flagellated protozoans in the urine or in a saline wet mount.

Trichomoniasis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, often presents with a yellow-green, diffuse, malodorous vaginal discharge. Symptoms can include pelvic and abdominal pain, and upon examination, "strawberry" cervix (erythematous cervix with pinpoint areas of exudation) may be noted.

Trichomonas vaginitis is associated with yellowish-green vaginal discharge, which may be frothy and have a foul smell. Other symptoms can include vaginal burning, itching, pain with urination, and pain with sexual intercourse. The condition is diagnosed by examining a discharge sample under a microscope for moving trichomonads.

Impaired cartilage proliferation in the growth plate is a common cause of dwarfism, associated with an activating mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3). This mutation inhibits growth, particularly affecting endochondral bone formation, which is characterized by the formation of a cartilage matrix replaced by bone, allowing long bones to grow. Intramembranous bone formation, which develops flat bones, is not affected.
Loop diuretics act on the Na+-K+-2Cl− symporter (NKCC2) in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle to inhibit sodium, chloride, and potassium reabsorption.

Surgery is usually recommended when the diameter of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) grows to >5.5 cm in males and >5.0 cm in females. Other reasons for repair include the presence of symptoms and a rapid increase in size, defined as more than one centimeter per year. Repair may be either by open surgery or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Compared to open surgery, EVAR has a lower risk of death in the short term and a shorter hospital stay, but may not always be an option. There does not appear to be a difference in longer-term outcomes between the two. Repeat procedures are more common with EVAR.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may occur during the ligature of the inferior thyroid artery. Unilateral damage results in a hoarse voice, and bilateral damage presents as laryngeal obstruction after surgery.
Damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can produce a hoarse voice after thyroid surgery.

Isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) deficiency (IGD) is characterized by inactivating mutations of the gonadotropin-releasing hormone receptor (GnRHR), resulting in insensitivity to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and a loss of the ability of the gonads to synthesize sex hormones. This condition presents with symptoms such as delayed, reduced, or absent puberty, low or complete lack of libido, and infertility. It is the predominant cause of isolated hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (IHH) when not associated with anosmia.
Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase 3 inhibitor which works by inhibiting platelet aggregation and dilating arteries.
Cilostazol is a selective phosphodiesterase (PDE3) inhibitor used for the treatment of intermittent claudication.

Jaundice (Hyperbilirubinemia) is common in newborn babies, occurring in roughly 60% to 84% of infants. It presents as yellow discoloration of the skin and whites of the eyes. Bilirubin is produced as a byproduct of hemoglobin breakdown and is metabolized in the liver. Excess bilirubin can indicate that the liver is too immature to eliminate it or that the body is producing too much. Breastfeeding frequently in the first few days can help lower the chances of developing jaundice. Poor latch may result in inadequate milk consumption, which can influence jaundice.

Jaundice on the first day of life is always pathologic and requires immediate attention. Breast milk jaundice may occur during the first to second week of life and is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia without evidence of hemolysis. Interruption of breastfeeding for 1 to 2 days results in a rapid decline of bilirubin levels. Early onset jaundice is often related to hemolysis, internal hemorrhage, or infection.

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is a condition in which the growth plate of the head of the femur slips over the underlying bone. It commonly presents with hip pain in males during puberty and is associated with obesity. The majority of those affected have a painful limp, and treatment involves non-weight-bearing movement and surgery. If not identified early, osteonecrosis or death of the head of the femur may occur.

Gross hematuria and flank pain can be caused by renal papillary necrosis, which may occur due to chronic analgesic abuse, such as long-term use of analgesics like phenacetin or aspirin. Additionally, renal papillary necrosis presents with symptoms such as hematuria and flank pain.

Buprenorphine is a partial μ-opioid receptor agonist and a weak κ-opioid receptor antagonist. It binds strongly to opioid receptors in the CNS, producing analgesic effects, but its efficacy is only partial compared to a full agonist. At higher doses, buprenorphine acts like an antagonist.

Advance directives include living wills and durable powers of attorney for health care, documenting the patient's expressed wishes. These directives guide family members and healthcare professionals in decision-making when the patient is incapacitated. The concept of "substituted judgment" allows a family member to give consent for treatment if the patient is unable to do so. The key question for the decision-making surrogate is what the patient would want in the situation.

Patients and family members can complete a do not resuscitate (DNR) order to indicate they do not wish to receive resuscitation. DNRs are generally justified for patients who might not benefit from CPR or those who prefer not to prolong the dying process.

Primary herpetic gingivostomatitis (PHGS) is caused predominantly by HSV-1 and affects mainly children. Symptoms include painful ulcerations, vesicular lesions in the mouth, fever, and lymphadenitis. Signs can include inability to eat or drink due to pain.

Herpes gingivostomatitis involves the gingivae and the vermilion border of the lips, and its clinical manifestations include typical oropharyngeal vesicular lesions, high fever, stinging mouth pain, drooling, fetid breath, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

The radial nerve, when affected, leads to wrist drop, finger extension weakness, and sensory loss in the dorsal web between the thumb and index finger. Most cases of radial neuropathy are transient and recover within 6–8 weeks. If there is severe axonal damage, recovery may take several months.

Intermittent claudication is most commonly due to peripheral arterial disease caused by significant atherosclerotic blockages resulting in arterial insufficiency. It is associated with smoking, hypertension, and diabetes. The symptoms include leg pain with walking that is relieved by rest.

Frontotemporal dementia is linked to tau-staining material in neurons and is associated with tau gene mutations that lead to tau accumulation and hyperphosphorylation. Intraneural deposition of tau is most striking in the frontotemporal cortex and the substantia nigra.

Blocking the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors in pulmonary smooth muscle tissue results in a decrease in smooth muscle tone and bronchodilation. Short-acting muscarinic antagonists (SAMAs) such as ipratropium and long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMA) such as tiotropium are included in this category.

Kallmann syndrome is associated with a lack of a sense of smell due to the altered migration of GnRH neurons on the olfactory placode. Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (CHH) in men features very low serum levels of inhibin B, indicating a potential issue with Sertoli cell number. Additionally, CHH can be diagnosed in male neonates presenting with cryptorchidism and micropenis, and anterior pituitary function must be normal for other axes in CHH as it is an isolated disorder.

Ipratropium bromide exhibits broncholytic action by reducing cholinergic influence on the bronchial musculature. It promotes the degradation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), resulting in a decreased intracellular concentration of cGMP, which leads to decreased contractility of smooth muscle in the lung, inhibiting bronchoconstriction and mucus secretion.

Conductive hearing loss should be assumed to be present with persistent middle ear effusion, which is commonly a sequela of acute otitis media (OM). In children with significant bilateral hearing loss due to persistent effusion, intervention with insertion of pressure equalization tubes is a reasonable approach.

If a patient experiences psychotic symptoms only during a mood episode, the diagnosis is Mood Disorder with Psychotic Features, not Schizophrenia or Schizoaffective Disorder. Psychotic symptoms lasting without mood symptoms for longer than two weeks could indicate Schizophrenia or Schizoaffective Disorder. If mood disorder episodes are present for the majority of the illness, the diagnosis can be Schizoaffective Disorder.

Vascular dementia is characterized by cognitive decline and memory impairment severe enough to interfere with daily activities. It may present with focal neurologic signs, including hemiparesis, hyperreflexia, and gait problems. The symptoms can progress gradually over 5–10 years and can be associated with cerebrovascular disease evidence on brain imaging.

If a woman is already receiving carbimazole, a change to propylthiouracil is recommended. Radioactive iodine is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. Medical therapy with anti-thyroid medications is the treatment of choice for hyperthyroidism in pregnancy. Methimazole and propylthiouracil are effective in preventing pregnancy complications by hyperthyroidism.

Propylthiouracil is classified as Drug Class D in pregnancy, indicating positive evidence of human fetal risk. It is preferred over methimazole only in the first trimester of pregnancy due to the increased risk of teratogenicity of methimazole during critical organogenesis. In the second and third trimester, the risk of teratogenicity is diminished, and methimazole is preferred to avoid the risk of liver complications from propylthiouracil in the mother.

Erythema marginatum presents as pink rings on the torso and inner surfaces of the limbs and is associated with rheumatic fever, which can occur in the context of a Group A streptococcal infection. It is considered a major criterion for diagnosing rheumatic fever along with carditis, polyarthritis, Sydenham's chorea, and subcutaneous nodules.

Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) are used primarily for the treatment of hypertension in patients intolerant of ACE inhibitor therapy due to persistent dry cough. ARBs are less frequently associated with cough and angioedema compared to ACE inhibitors.
Enalapril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, lowers blood pressure. It can cause a persistent cough and angioedema in some patients.

The diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is almost always made endoscopically, often through proctoscopy. Characteristic findings in more advanced disease include mucosal friability and ulceration, with the earliest manifestation being mucosal edema that results in a loss of the normal vascular pattern. Continuous mucosal damage is a key aspect of ulcerative colitis.

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is characterized by painless, acute vision loss in one eye. Fundoscopic examination may reveal a cherry-red spot, retinal opacity, pallor, retinal arterial attenuation, and optic disk edema. The most common cause of CRAO is carotid artery atherosclerosis.

MPGN (Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis) can result from glomerular deposition of circulating immune complexes or their in situ formation. Types II and III MPGN may be related to "nephritic factors," such as autoantibodies that stabilize C3 convertase, allowing it to activate serum C3.
