Damage to the axillary nerve affects function of the teres minor and deltoid muscles, resulting in loss of abduction of the arm (from 15-90 degrees) as well as loss of sensation of the skin over a small part of the lateral shoulder.

Nomifensine is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor, increasing the synaptic availability of norepinephrine and dopamine by blocking their reuptake transporters. The (S)-isomer of the drug is responsible for its activity.

Thyroid cancer often presents as a painless mass in the neck, and it is unusual for thyroid cancers to present with other symptoms. Most malignant thyroid cancers are papillary, followed by follicular, medullary, and thyroid lymphoma. A solitary nodule that is fixed to surrounding tissues and nontender may suggest malignancy. Normal TSH levels and negative antithyroid antibodies can indicate that the nodule is not hyperfunctioning or related to autoimmune thyroiditis.

The most common cause of Wernicke's aphasia is a stroke, which typically occurs due to an occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery, which supplies blood to areas involved in speech, language, and swallowing, including Wernicke's area.

Colesevelam binds bile acids in the intestine, impeding their reabsorption. It can increase the demand for cholesterol in the liver cells, resulting in increased clearance of LDL-C from the blood. However, it is important to separate the timing of colesevelam dosing from other medications due to its mechanism of action.

Colesevelam is a bile acid sequestrant indicated for reducing elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) in patients with primary hyperlipidemia and for improving glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is important to note that the timing of the dosing of colesevelam should be separated from other medications, as it can affect the absorption of those medications.

Colesevelam is a bile acid binding resin that functions by binding bile acids, increasing their excretion, and is useful for decreasing LDL cholesterol. The most common side effects include bloating and diarrhea.

The rotator cuff tear involves injury to one or more of the tendons or muscles of the rotator cuff, which consists of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis. The supraspinatus is the most commonly affected tendon. Symptoms of a rotator cuff tear may include shoulder pain, weakness, and difficulty with movement, particularly in external rotation and abduction.

For the diagnosis of a full-thickness rotator cuff tear, key tests include the painful arc sign, weakness in external rotation, and the drop arm sign (Codman's test), where the arm is raised to 90° and drops suddenly or causes pain when attempting to lower it.

Subcutaneous nodules occur as painless, small (0.5–2 cm), mobile lumps beneath the skin over bony prominences, particularly of the hands, feet, elbows, and occasionally the vertebrae. They are commonly associated with carditis. Fever occurs in most cases of ARF, although rarely in cases of pure chorea.

Subcutaneous nodules are firm, painless, nonpruritic, mobile nodules found on the extensor surfaces of large and small joints. Chorea (Sydenham chorea) consists of neurologic and psychiatric signs and is often present long after the infection.

The most common clinical finding in acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is a migratory arthritis involving multiple joints. One of the minor Jones Criteria includes subcutaneous nodules. The presence of involuntary, purposeless movement known as Sydenham chorea is also associated with ARF.

Clozapine is usually used for individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia who have had an inadequate response to other antipsychotics or have been unable to tolerate other drugs due to extrapyramidal side effects. It is regarded as the gold-standard treatment when other medication has been insufficiently effective. Clozapine treatment has been demonstrated to produce improved outcomes in multiple domains, including a reduced risk of hospitalization, reduced risk of drug discontinuation, and improved efficacy in treating positive psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia.

Clozapine is prescribed for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, which is the failure to respond to two or more antipsychotic medications. Clozapine has a risk of agranulocytosis, requiring blood tests for the first six months of treatment.

Clozapine is an effective treatment for those who respond poorly to other drugs ("treatment-resistant" or "refractory" schizophrenia), but it has the potentially serious side effect of agranulocytosis (lowered white blood cell count) in less than 4% of people.
Clozapine can cause agranulocytosis (a decreased number of white blood cells), requiring blood monitoring for the patient.

Ketamine is used for pain treatment in individuals with refractory pain, especially in the perioperative period. It is likely to be beneficial for surgical patients when severe post-operative pain is expected and for opioid-tolerant patients.

Atracurium is a neuromuscular blocking agent that inhibits neuron transmission to muscle by blocking the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction, acting as a competitive antagonist against acetylcholine.

C1-inhibitor deficiency is associated with hereditary angioedema, which presents as recurrent episodes of swelling in the face, mouth, and/or airway that can occur spontaneously or in response to minimal triggers. The condition is characterized by low levels of C1-inhibitor in 85% of cases, while 15% involve dysfunctional but normal levels of the protein. The symptoms typically resolve in 2 to 3 days.

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) should be considered in patients with recurrent angioedema without urticaria, recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and vomiting, and a positive family history of angioedema. C1-inhibitor levels are low in HAE, particularly in type I, which is responsible for approximately 80–85% of cases. Low C1 inhibitor (C1-INH) functional levels are essential for diagnosis.

Bacillus anthracis is a Gram-positive, spore-forming rod that produces anthrax toxin, which consists of protective antigen, lethal factor, and edema factor. It has a polypeptide capsule made of poly d-glutamate, which is a virulence factor that contributes to its survival in host tissue. Pulmonary anthrax can present with flu-like symptoms that rapidly progress to fever, pulmonary hemorrhage, mediastinitis, and shock, and is associated with inhalation of spores often from contaminated animal products.
The lethality of anthrax is due to the poly-D-glutamic acid capsule, which protects the bacterium from phagocytosis by host neutrophils.

Patients with third-and fourth-degree lacerations at delivery are associated with an increased risk of fecal incontinence (odds ratio [OR] 3.09). Approximately one-third of patients with occult anal sphincter tears have symptoms of anal incontinence. Forceps-assisted vaginal delivery significantly increases the risk of anal incontinence, while the data on vacuum-assisted delivery are less conclusive.

Among women who experience a third or fourth degree perineal tear, 60-80% are asymptomatic after 12 months. Faecal incontinence, faecal urgency, chronic perineal pain, pain with sex, and fistula formation occur in a minority of women, but may be permanent.

In diabetes mellitus type 2, there is an accumulation of amyloid in the pancreatic islets, which likely disrupts their anatomy and physiology. The pathogenesis involves a reduced population of islet beta-cells, reduced secretory function of the surviving beta-cells, and peripheral tissue insulin resistance. Type 2 diabetes is characterized by increased glucagon secretion that is unresponsive to blood glucose levels.

Phyllodes tumors are large, fast-growing masses that form from the periductal stromal cells of the breast. They account for less than 1% of all breast neoplasms and predominantly occur in adult women, most commonly between the ages of 40 and 50. Patients with phyllodes tumors typically present with a firm, palpable mass that can increase in size within a few weeks.
Zenker diverticulum can present with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and halitosis (smelly breath). Food might get trapped in the outpouching, leading to regurgitation.

Zenker diverticulum is a pharyngoesophageal false diverticulum caused by esophageal dysmotility, resulting in herniation of mucosal tissue at Killian triangle. Presenting symptoms include dysphagia, obstruction, gurgling, aspiration, and foul breath (halitosis). It is most common in elderly males.

Zenker’s diverticulum typically occurs in elderly patients and is associated with dysphagia, regurgitation of particulate food debris, aspiration, and halitosis. The pathogenesis involves stenosis of the cricopharyngeus, leading to increased hypopharyngeal pressure during swallowing and the development of a pulsion diverticulum above the cricopharyngeus. A cricopharyngeal bar is related to Zenker’s diverticulum, as it involves limited distensibility of the cricopharyngeus.

Zenker’s diverticula result from increased intraluminal pressure associated with distal obstruction, specifically from a stenotic cricopharyngeus muscle. Symptoms of Zenker’s diverticula can include dysphagia and halitosis.

Clomipramine is a reuptake inhibitor of serotonin and norepinephrine, specifically blocking their reuptake into neurons, which increases their extracellular concentrations in the synaptic cleft and results in increased serotonergic and noradrenergic neurotransmission.
The antidepressant effects of clomipramine are thought to be due to reuptake inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine.

Clomipramine is an antidepressant that is used to treat clinical depression and is effective for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). It decreases the breakdown of serotonin and norepinephrine by blocking their reuptake, thereby increasing their levels in the synaptic cleft.
Clomipramine is an antidepressant that inhibits the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine, resulting in higher concentrations of these neurotransmitters in the brain.

People with Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) often experience weakness that is less severe than expected based on symptoms, with strength improving on repeated testing, such as improvement of power on repeated hand grip, known as "Lambert's sign." Reflexes are typically reduced at rest, but increase with muscle use, which is characteristic of LEMS. Sluggish pupillary light reflex may also be observed. Disruption of the autonomic nervous system in LEMS can lead to symptoms such as dry mouth, constipation, blurred vision, impaired sweating, and orthostatic hypotension.

The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) is the main central connection for the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and abducens nerve. Lesions of the MLF can cause diplopia, which may be associated with conditions such as multiple sclerosis, a neoplasm, or a stroke.

A lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus produces slowed or absent adduction of the ipsilateral eye upon contralateral gaze and is usually associated with involuntary jerky eye movements (nystagmus) of the abducting eye, a syndrome known as internuclear ophthalmoplegia. This can occur due to demyelination of the axons in conditions like multiple sclerosis, presenting as nystagmus and diplopia.

The medial longitudinal fasciculus carries information about the direction that the eyes should move. It connects the nuclei of the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the abducens nerve (CN VI). It is integral to saccadic eye movements and vestibulo-ocular reflex.

The diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid includes clinical assessment, skin biopsy for histopathology, and direct immunofluorescence. Direct immunofluorescence is the gold standard for diagnosis. Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by blistering skin disease, particularly in patients over 70 years old, with tense blisters and erosions occurring without another identifiable cause. Typical histopathologic findings include the presence of linear deposits of C3 and IgG along the basement membrane on direct immunofluorescence.

Diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid consists of at least 2 positive results out of 3 criteria: (1) pruritus and/or predominant cutaneous blisters, (2) linear IgG and/or C3c deposits by direct immunofluorescence microscopy on a skin biopsy specimen, and (3) positive epidermal side staining by indirect immunofluorescence microscopy on human salt-split skin.

Aortic stenosis presents with a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the upper right sternal border, which radiates to the carotid arteries. The murmur is accentuated by squatting and decreases with standing and the Valsalva maneuver. The intensity of the murmur increases with the severity of stenosis, and the peak occurs later in the crescendo-decrescendo profile as the stenosis becomes more severe.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by hypertrophy of the interventricular septum causing outflow obstruction of the left ventricle. It commonly presents with dyspnea and chest pain during daily activities and may lead to syncope. Physical examination findings include a loud systolic murmur and a palpable triple apical impulse due to a palpable presystolic fourth heart sound.

Individuals with advanced sleep phase disorder (ASPD) report being unable to stay awake until conventional bedtime, falling asleep early in the evening, and experiencing early morning insomnia. Their melatonin levels and core body temperature cycle hours earlier than average. Diagnosis involves measuring sleep patterns and may include assessments like polysomnography to rule out other disorders.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by proteinuria (often in the nephrotic range of >3.5 g/day), low serum albumin (<3.5 g/dL), susceptibility to infection due to loss of serum antibodies, and may show fatty casts in the urine. Common symptoms include frothy urine due to excess protein and edema due to loss of serum albumin.

Infections from shigellosis can lead to possible sequelae such as reactive arthritis and hemolytic uremic syndrome. Symptoms of shigellosis include diarrhea with blood and mucus, which aligns with the patient's presentation.

Total proctocolectomy is curative for longstanding or fulminant colitis or toxic megacolon and also decreases cancer risk. There is a markedly increased risk of colorectal cancer in longstanding cases, necessitating frequent fecal occult blood screening and yearly colonoscopy with multiple biopsies after eight years of disease.

Anasarca is a severe and generalized form of edema reflecting a severe disease state, often caused by decreased oncotic pressure due to conditions like organ failure, malignancy, or severe protein deficiency. Symptoms include lower extremity edema, which can manifest as bilateral pedal and ankle swelling.

Anti-endomysial (EMA) antibodies of the immunoglobulin A (IgA) type can detect coeliac disease with high sensitivity and specificity, especially in patients with villous atrophy. Serology for anti-transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG) has a sensitivity of 99% and specificity of over 90%. Both antibodies have high sensitivity to diagnose individuals with classic symptoms and complete villous atrophy.

The diagnosis of celiac disease requires the detection of characteristic histologic changes on small-intestinal biopsy, including an increase in the number of intraepithelial lymphocytes, absence or a reduced height of villi, which causes a flat appearance, increased crypt cell proliferation resulting in crypt hyperplasia, and loss of villous structure. Positive immunological assays for anti-transglutaminase and anti-endomysial antibodies can also indicate celiac disease.

Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-tTG or anti-TG2) are found in patients with several conditions, including celiac disease. In celiac disease, ATA are involved in the destruction of the villous extracellular matrix and target the destruction of intestinal villous epithelial cells by killer cells.

Consistent condom use reduces the risk of HIV transmission by approximately 80% over the long term. When condoms are used consistently by a couple in which one person is infected, the rate of HIV infection is less than 1% per year. There is evidence suggesting that nonoxynol-9 spermicide may increase the risk of HIV transmission due to vaginal and rectal irritation.

Bacterial infections leading to gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis can be prevented by sexual abstinence, use of barrier contraception such as condoms, pre-exposure vaccination (HPV and Hepatitis B vaccines), and reducing the number of sexual partners.

Consistent and correct use of male latex condoms can reduce the risk of STD transmission. Inconsistent use can lead to STD acquisition because transmission can occur with a single act of intercourse. The most reliable ways to avoid transmission of STDs are to abstain from sexual activity or to be in a long-term mutually monogamous relationship with an uninfected partner.
Some individuals with medullary cystic kidney disease develop gout, which is a condition characterized by severe pain and swelling in joints, such as the big toe.

Patients with pes anserine bursitis typically present with pain at the medial knee when climbing stairs or rising from chairs. They may also report tenderness in the medial knee joint and along the medial tendons of the pes anserinus when the knee is flexed. The likelihood of pes anserine bursitis is increased in patients with osteoarthritis. Imaging is not commonly used for diagnosis.

Pes anserine bursitis is characterized by pain at the medial knee and upper tibial region, particularly exacerbated by activities such as climbing stairs. It is associated with localized tenderness, and the condition may result from stress, overuse, obesity, and trauma to the area.
Early pregnancy (<8 weeks’ gestational age) can be terminated medically with oral mifepristone (RU-486) in combination with misoprostol, methotrexate with misoprostol, or misoprostol alone.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) is an inflammatory autoimmune disease of large blood vessels, which can lead to complications such as blockage of the artery to the eye resulting in blindness, aortic dissection, and aortic aneurysm. The underlying mechanism involves inflammation of small blood vessels within larger arteries, mainly affecting arteries around the head and neck, but some in the chest may also be involved. Symptoms include headaches, pain over the temples, flu-like symptoms, double vision, and difficulty opening the mouth. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy of the temporal artery, which may show transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina.

Trichomonas vaginitis is an infection associated with yellowish-green vaginal discharge that can be frothy and may have a foul smell. Symptoms include vaginal burning or itching and pain with urination. The organism is diagnosed by examining a sample of discharge under a microscope for trichomonads. In women, the organism is typically detected in only 60-80% of cases.
Damage to the left frontal lobe is associated with speech impairments, particularly in relation to Broca's area and Broca’s Aphasia.
A gluten-free diet is the recommended management for patients with celiac sprue.

Age is the most important factor in female infertility, with 81% of variation in ovarian reserve attributed to age alone. A typical woman has 12% of her ovarian reserve at age 30 and only 3% at age 40. Methods for checking ovarian reserve include blood tests for serum Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) levels, as well as Antral Follicle Count via transvaginal ultrasound.
In overt primary hypothyroidism, TSH levels are high and T4 and T3 levels are low. It may be diagnosed with a TSH greater than 5mIU/L and appropriate symptoms, or a TSH greater than 10mIU/L.
The most useful marker of thyroid gland function is serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. Elevated TSH levels can signify inadequate thyroid hormone production (hypothyroidism).

The history of U.S court cases regarding Jehovah's Witnesses' refusal of blood transfusions rules in favor of the hospital, stating that the child’s interests and those of the state outweigh parental rights to refuse medical treatment. Parental rights do not grant absolute authority over life and death decisions concerning their children, especially in life-threatening situations.

A normal T score is -1.0 and above, low bone density is between -1.0 and -2.5, and osteoporosis is -2.5 and lower. The patient’s condition of osteopenia would correspond to a T score between -1.0 and -2.5.

Osteoporosis is defined in women by the World Health Organization as a bone mineral density of 2.5 standard deviations below peak bone mass. Osteopenia is a condition where bone mineral density is lower than normal but not low enough to be classified as osteoporosis. DEXA scans are used to measure bone mineral density, and results are often expressed as T-scores, with a T-score between -1 and -2.5 indicating osteopenia.

Bone density between 1 and 2.5 standard deviations below the reference, or a T-score between −1.0 and −2.5, indicates osteopenia. The ISCD recommends using Caucasian women between 20 and 29 years old as the baseline for bone density for all patients. The ISCD recommends that Z-scores, not T-scores, be used to classify bone density in premenopausal women and men under 50.
Bacterial causes of upper respiratory infections include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Bordetella pertussis, and Bacillus anthracis.

Glycogen storage disease type II, also known as Pompe disease, is caused by a deficiency of the lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase enzyme. The disease leads to an accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome, resulting in progressive muscle weakness (myopathy) and affects various body tissues, particularly the heart, skeletal muscles, liver, and nervous system. The infantile form typically presents with signs including cardiomegaly, hypotonia, cardiomyopathy, respiratory distress, muscle weakness, feeding difficulties, and failure to thrive.

Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) is a hematopoietic growth factor that, along with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF), increases the concentration of hematopoietic progenitor cells in the blood following administration. This is particularly relevant during recovery from intensive chemotherapy, which may be the situation for the patient undergoing allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.
The most frequently isolated anaerobic bacteria in polymicrobial infections associated with abdominal infections are the B. fragilis group, Peptostreptococcus spp., and Clostridium spp.

Anaerobic infections can involve the B. fragilis group, which is commonly associated with complications from infections like secondary peritonitis. The clinical manifestations include fever, abdominal pain, and signs of peritoneal inflammation. In complicated infections, especially those related to carcinoma or following bile tract surgery, anaerobes such as B. fragilis are often recovered.
Intraabdominal infections are usually polymicrobial and often involve Escherichia coli (found in ≥50% of patients) and B. fragilis (30–50%) among other anaerobes.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) most often first manifests as inflammation of particular finger or toe joints, however, pain and swelling of larger joints, including the knees, may also be the first sign. Reactive arthritis often presents with lower limb oligoarthritis, including that of the knee. Gouty arthritis is characterized by arthritis of a single joint of the lower extremities with rapid onset, and while the knee may be affected, skin symptoms occur less often.

Dermatomyositis is characterized by skin rashes and muscle weakness. Symptoms include purplish or lilac rashes around the eyes (heliotrope) and "shawl" rashes on the neck and upper chest, as well as red or violet papules (Gottron's sign) on finger joints and bony prominences. These rashes can be worsened by sunlight exposure and may be itchy, painful, and may bleed.

Psoriatic arthritis occurs in 5-10% of patients who have psoriasis. The classic presentation involves the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, with symptoms such as morning stiffness, deformity of involved joints, dactylitis, and nail involvement. Well-demarcated red plaques with silvery scaling are characteristic lesions of psoriasis.
The UK guidelines emphasize calcium channel blockers (CCB) in preference for individuals over the age of 55 years or those of African or Caribbean descent.

The recommended blood pressure goal for elderly patients is advised as <150/90 mm Hg. First-line medications in the United States for treating hypertension include thiazide diuretics, calcium-channel blockers (CCB), angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI), or angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARB).

Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is an allergic inflammatory condition of the esophagus that involves eosinophils. Symptoms include difficulty swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, and heartburn. EoE can occur in adults and may be triggered by food allergies. Diagnosis can be challenging due to non-specific symptoms and histopathologic findings. Treatment may involve removal of trigger foods and medications to suppress the immune response.
Eosinophilic esophagitis is commonly associated with other atopic diseases such as asthma, food allergies, seasonal allergies, and atopic skin disease.

Wilson's disease (WD) is a rare inherited disorder in which patients have a problem metabolizing copper. In patients with WD, copper accumulates in the liver and other parts of the body, particularly the brain, eyes, and kidneys.

Patients with severe hirsutism, virilization, or rapidly progressing signs of androgen excess require investigation for androgen-secreting neoplasms, commonly from the adrenal glands or ovaries. Signs may include hirsutism, acne, and virilization. Specific tests for androgens and imaging techniques are used for assessment. Bioavailable testosterone levels, alongside other hormonal tests, are critical in diagnosing and characterizing hyperandrogenism.

Basal levels of 17α-hydroxyprogesterone higher than 800 ng/dL are virtually diagnostic of CAH. Levels between 300 and 800 ng/dL require stimulatory testing with corticotropin to distinguish between PCOS and CAH. Nonclassic 21-hydroxylase deficiency may occur even when basal levels of 17α-hydroxyprogesterone are below 300 ng/dL, thus requiring stimulatory testing in those cases.
The commonly occluded coronary arteries are: LAD (left anterior descending artery) > RCA (right coronary artery) > circumflex artery.

Osteitis fibrosa cystica is caused by hyperparathyroidism, which leads to a surplus of parathyroid hormone from over-active parathyroid glands. This condition results in a loss of bone mass, replacement of calcified bone structures with fibrous tissue, and the formation of cyst-like brown tumors in and around the bone. Osteoclastic bone resorption is stimulated, releasing minerals such as calcium from the bone into the bloodstream.

Posttraumatic stress disorder often proceeds from experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event involving death, serious injury, or significant threat to others or oneself. Disturbing intrusive images, often described as 'flashbacks', are a common symptom of this condition.

Individuals suffering from posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) exhibit a heightened startle response to benign stimuli and may experience psychological and physiological reactions to triggers associated with their trauma. Common symptoms include upsetting dreams, anxiety, and disturbing flashbacks, especially in response to stimuli reminiscent of the traumatic experience, such as loud noises that can evoke memories of combat situations.
Elastase is a serine protease released by neutrophils that disrupts elastin and components of the alveolar wall, which can lead to emphysema and chronic bronchitis in patients with A1AT deficiency.
The underlying mechanism of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (A1AD) involves unblocked neutrophil elastase, which can lead to lung disease.
AAT deficiency permits increased elastase activity to destroy elastin in the alveolar walls.

Rosiglitazone has been associated with an increase in severe cardiac events, although thiazolidinediones are generally established to have beneficial effects on diabetes and are recommended as first, second, or third line agents for type 2 diabetes mellitus by the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE). However, thiazolidinediones are less preferred than GLP-1 agonists or SGLT2 inhibitors, especially in patients with cardiovascular disease.

Liraglutide is used for the treatment of type 2 diabetes. It improves control of blood glucose and may also be used for chronic weight management in patients with a body mass index (BMI) greater than 30 kg/m², or greater than 27 kg/m² with comorbidities like high blood pressure or type 2 diabetes.

Empagliflozin is used in combination with diet and exercise to help lower blood sugar levels in people with type 2 diabetes. It can be used alongside other medications like metformin. Empagliflozin causes moderate reductions in blood pressure and body weight, with an average weight loss of 2% from baseline and systolic blood pressure reductions of 3 to 5 mmHg.

B12 deficiency, also known as hypocobalaminemia, often results from absorption complications and is commonly associated with pernicious anemia. This autoimmune disorder destroys cells that produce intrinsic factor, hindering B12 absorption. B12 deficiency can lead to symptoms of anemia, such as pale skin, dizziness, and fatigue.
Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and therefore should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant primarily used to support smoking cessation. It carries a much higher risk of seizure than many other antidepressants, and extreme caution must be taken in patients with a history of seizure disorder.
C: Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.
C: Bupropion lowers the seizure threshold and it should not be taken by patients with a history of seizure disorder.

The blood smear of a person with iron-deficiency anemia shows many hypochromic (pale, relatively colorless) and small red blood cells, and may also show poikilocytosis (variation in shape) and anisocytosis (variation in size). With more severe iron-deficiency anemia, the peripheral blood smear may show hypochromic, pencil-shaped cells and, occasionally, small numbers of nucleated red blood cells. The platelet count may be slightly above the high limit of normal in iron-deficiency anemia (termed a mild thrombocytosis), but severe cases can present with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).

NSAID anti-inflammatory activity is mediated chiefly through inhibition of prostaglandin biosynthesis. Various NSAIDs have additional possible mechanisms of action, including inhibition of chemotaxis, down-regulation of IL-1 production, decreased production of free radicals and superoxide, and interference with calcium-mediated intracellular events.

Avoiding foods that are high in fat and high in oxalate (such as nuts, pepper, chocolate, rhubarb, spinach, dark green vegetables, and fruits) can help reduce hyperoxaluria (excessive urinary excretion of oxalate). Reducing the amount of meats and other purine-containing foods suppresses hyperuricosuria (increased amounts of uric acid in the urine). Increasing fluid intake will increase urine volume and dilute the stone-forming salts to below the upper risk levels.

Aside from vigorous oral hydration and eating more dietary calcium, other prevention strategies for kidney stones include avoidance of large doses of supplemental and restriction of oxalate-rich foods such as leaf vegetables, rhubarb, soy products, and chocolate. Some evidence indicates magnesium intake decreases the risk of symptomatic kidney stones.

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones include higher urine calcium, higher urine oxalate, and lower urine citrate. Increasing urine volume to at least 2 L/day can reduce the likelihood of crystal formation.
Proton pump inhibitors have been implicated in increased bone loss and fractures.

Waxy casts suggest very low urine flow associated with severe, longstanding kidney disease such as kidney failure. They are significantly larger than hyaline casts and are seen in chronic kidney failure. Broad casts describe the wider cast product of a dilated duct, which is also present in chronic kidney failure.

Circulating oxalate can complex with plasma calcium, reducing the ionized calcium. Therapy must be initiated in patients with severe metabolic acidosis and elevated anion and osmolar gaps. Other diagnostic features, such as hypocalcemia or acute renal failure with crystalluria, can provide important confirmation for urgent, empiric therapy.

Large anion gap acidosis is usually present during the initial stage of ethylene glycol poisoning. The diagnosis should be considered in any people with severe acidosis. Urine microscopy can reveal needle or envelope-shaped calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

Phenoxybenzamine is used to avoid the effects of unopposed α stimulation (i.e., hypertensive crisis and congestive heart failure) and is typically initiated 3 to 4 days preoperatively. Other α-blockers such as prazosin, terazosin, and doxazosin have a better side effect profile and are preferable when long-term pharmacologic therapy is needed for patients with metastatic pheochromocytoma.
Phenoxybenzamine (irreversible a-blocker) followed by a beta-blocker is administered preoperatively to prevent a hypertensive crisis in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Bottle-fed infants should receive an iron-containing formula until 12 months of age, and breastfed infants older than 6 months should receive an iron supplement. The introduction of iron-enriched solid foods at 6 months of age can help prevent iron deficiency anemia. Teenage girls who are menstruating should have a diet enriched with iron-containing foods. A vitamin with iron may also be used.

Epinephrine stimulates β-adrenergic receptors causing relaxation of airway smooth muscles, which leads to bronchodilation, and stimulates α-adrenergic receptors which reverses life-threatening cardiovascular effects.

A Bartholin's cyst occurs when a Bartholin's gland becomes blocked, potentially resulting in swelling and pain, especially during sex or walking. If the cyst becomes uncomfortable or painful, drainage is recommended, with the preferred method being the insertion of a Word catheter for four weeks due to the common recurrence following simple incision and drainage.

The mode of inheritance for SCARF syndrome is perceived to be X-linked recessive because it has been observed in male cousins related through their mothers. This means that the gene associated with this disorder is located on the X chromosome and only a single mutation is needed to cause the disorder in males.

Mefloquine is the only drug advised for pregnant women traveling to areas with drug-resistant malaria; it is generally considered safe in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy. Chloroquine and proguanil are regarded as safe for use in pregnancy.

Doxycycline (100 mg daily) is an effective alternative for pre-exposure prophylaxis against malaria and is generally well tolerated but cannot be used by children <8 years old or by pregnant women. Chloroquine is no longer reliable for preventing P. falciparum infections in most areas but is used for other human Plasmodium species and for P. falciparum malaria in certain Central American countries.

Doxycycline and the combination of atovaquone/proguanil (Malarone) are frequently used for prevention of malaria and are better tolerated. Mefloquine is taken once a week but may not be as well tolerated. Areas with chloroquine-sensitive malaria are uncommon.

Mefloquine is used for the prevention of malaria in areas without resistant parasites and is recommended by the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as a first or second-line agent for malaria prophylaxis, depending on resistance patterns. It is typically taken for one to two weeks before entering an area with malaria.

Exenatide is believed to facilitate glucose control by increasing insulin secretion from the pancreas in response to meals, suppressing the pancreatic release of glucagon, and slowing gastric emptying. However, it is indicated for patients who can produce some insulin, as type 1 diabetes results in insufficient insulin production.

Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist (GLP-1 receptor agonist) that increases insulin release from the pancreas and decreases excessive glucagon release. It is used to treat diabetes mellitus type 2, but the document does not indicate its effectiveness or appropriateness for patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus. Common side effects include low blood sugar, nausea, dizziness, abdominal pain, and pain at the site of injection.

Integrase inhibitors act by blocking the action of the HIV integrase enzyme, preventing integration of the HIV provirus into the host cell genome. The three licensed integrase inhibitors are raltegravir, elvitegravir, and dolutegravir.

The patient has Lyme disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted by the bite of a tick in the genus Ixodes. Infected ticks are endemic in the Northeast region of the United States.
Simvastatin can cause serious side effects, including liver problems, which may lead to elevated liver function tests. A lower dose may be needed in people with kidney problems.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome occurs primarily in young children due to a toxin-producing strain of Staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an abrupt fever and a diffused sunburned appearance of the rash, associated with tenderness and large blister formation that easily pop, leading to skin peeling. The rash can resemble scarlet fever but the affected skin is tender.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) presents with the widespread formation of fluid-filled blisters that are thin-walled and easily ruptured, along with a positive Nikolsky's sign. The syndrome also includes widespread painful erythroderma, often involving the face and diaper areas, and extensive areas of desquamation. SSSS spares the mucous membranes and is most common in children under 6 years but can occur in adults who are immunosuppressed or have kidney failure.

Lichen sclerosus is the most common white lesion of the vulva, often occurring in postmenopausal women and prepubertal girls. Symptoms include pruritus, dyspareunia, and burning. It is characterized by decreased subcutaneous fat, atrophic vulva with small or absent labia minora, obliteration of anatomic landmarks, thin labia majora, and sometimes phimosis. The surface appears pale with a shiny, crinkled pattern and may have fissures and excoriation. The lesions are typically symmetric and can extend to perineal and perianal areas. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and there is an association between invasive cancer and lichen sclerosus, although the causation is unclear.

Lichen sclerosus is characterized by thinning of the epidermis, disappearance of rete pegs, acellular dermal fibrosis, and a bandlike mononuclear inflammatory cell infiltrate. It appears as smooth, white plaques or papules, and, when the entire vulva is affected, the labia become atrophic and stiffened. Symptoms include severe vulvar itching, pain during vaginal intercourse, and the presence of dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions. It occurs most commonly in postmenopausal women and prepubertal girls.

Entacapone is a selective and reversible inhibitor of catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT), which eliminates biologically active catechols present in catecholamines. It is given as an adjunct to levodopa and acts by inhibiting COMT in the periphery, leading to increased plasma levels of levodopa and more constant dopaminergic stimulation.

Common side effects of nifedipine include leg swelling. It is used for the long-term treatment of hypertension and is a calcium channel antagonist, which is favored as a primary treatment for patients over 55.
TSH level of 24.9 μIU/mL indicates hypothyroidism.

TSH deficiency leads to hypothyroidism, which presents with symptoms such as tiredness, fatigue, intolerance to cold, constipation, and weight gain. Hypothyroidism may cause slowed heart rate and low blood pressure.

The diagnosis of COPD is made when the FEV1/FVC ratio is less than 0.7 or the FEV1 is less than 75% of predicted. The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease criteria require that values are measured after bronchodilator medication. According to the European Respiratory Society criteria, COPD is defined when a patient's FEV1% is less than 88% of the predicted value for men, or less than 89% for women.
